awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Statistical Methods, Algorithms, and Theory for Large Tensors
awd_abstract_narration:
Large amounts of multidimensional data in the form of multilinear arrays, or tensors, arise routinely in modern applications from such diverse fields as chemometrics, genomics, physics, psychology, and signal processing, among many others. At the present time, our ability to generate and acquire such data has far outpaced our ability to effectively extract useful information. There is a clear need to develop novel statistical methods, efficient computational algorithms, and fundamental mathematical theory to analyze and exploit information in these types of data. This research project builds upon prior work in high-dimensional statistics, genomics, quantum physics, fast functional MRI, and closed-loop diabetes control to address the challenges in analysis of large tensorial data sets.  It is anticipated that the project will help to advance future research in these and other areas of applications.

One of the main challenges in dealing with this type of data is to develop methods of statistical inference to achieve both the statistical and computational efficiencies. More often than not, these two aims are not simultaneously achieved by existing methods: there is a gap between the optimal rate in the minimax sense and the best rate achievable by existing polynomial-time algorithms. The overarching goal of this project is to develop statistical methods, algorithms, and theory to efficiently, both statistically and computationally, analyze large scale data in the form of tensors. In particular, four most common and interrelated problems will be studied systematically: low-rank tensor denoising, low-rank tensor regression, estimation of the moment tensor, and tensor phase retrieval.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Rutgers University New Brunswick, Statistics Dept

por.por_cntn:
The project has studied the statistical optimal rate of convergence and the statistical performance of fast numerical algorithms, and their gap, in low-rank tensor denoising, low rank tensor regression and completion, and related problems and applications. This is achieved by developing new statistical methods and computational algorithms, theoretical study of their performance, and development of related mathematical tools and computational softwares. The project has achieved significant advances in developing methods and theory in tensor recovery, tensor factor models, statistical inference with high-dimensional data and nonparametric estimation. The project results were presented in many conferences and seminars. The project has developed and studied methods of estimating a low rank tensor from noisy observations on a subset of its entries to achieve both statistical and computational efficiencies. The project has constructed a polynomial-time computable estimating procedure based upon power iteration with a second-order spectral initialization that achieves the optimal rates of convergence. The project has developed multiplier and empirical bootstrap methods and theory for high-dimensional data. The project has developed statistical inference procedures including function estimation, limiting distribution theory and confidence intervals in multiple isotonic regression. The new approaches and solutions to these interesting and challenging problems have drawn substantial attention from researchers around the world. The new methodologies and theory developed in the project have a significant impact on the understanding of such problems in high-dimensional data analysis. High-dimensional data is an area of intense current interest in statistical research and practice due to the rapid development of information technologies and their applications to modern scientific experiments and everyday life. The methodologies developed in this project will have many applications in areas such as genomics, signal processing, neural imaging and communications networks, where statistical inference problems arise with large and complex data. The project directly impacts the development of human resources by training graduates students, collaborating with young researchers and by disseminating the project results through conference presentations, special and short courses, and scholastic websites. The project directly impacts on teaching and educational experiences by offering opportunities for graduates students to embark on interesting research problems and by enriching the teaching materials in statistics and machine leaning courses. 


Last Modified: 05/07/2022
Modified by: Cun-Hui Zhang
